question: A man at a point P on the shore of a circular lake of radius 1 mile wants to reach the point Q on the shore diametrically opposite P (Fig. 16-5). He can row 1.5 miles per hour and walk 3 miles per hour. At what angle $\theta $ ($0<\theta < \pi /2$) to the diameter PQ should he row in order to minimize the time required to reach Q? <image 1>
description: The image depicts a circular lake with a radius of 1 mile. Points P and Q are located on the circumference of the circle, with Q being diametrically opposite P. The center of the circle is labeled O. A line segment PR is drawn from point P to a point R on the circumference, forming an angle θ with the diameter PQ. Another line segment QR is also shown, forming an angle of 2θ with the diameter PQ. The angles θ and 2θ are clearly marked in the diagram. The goal is to determine the angle θ at which the man should row from P to R in order to minimize the time required to reach Q, given that he can row at 1.5 miles per hour and walk at 3 miles per hour.
